block.p: Theater

KINGS COUNTY SHAKESPEARE COMPANY'S FESTIVAL, through Sept. 3 at Founders Hall Theater of St. Francis College, 182 Remsen Street, Brooklyn Heights, will present Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' (tonight at 8) and Richard Brinsley Sheridan's comedy of manners ''The Rivals'' (tomorrow and Sunday at 8) in repertory. For children the highlight will be the preliminary performance at 7:15, ''Shakespeare's Clowns and Villains and Willie's Willful Women,'' featuring comic scenes from the plays, performed by the KCSC Young Company. Also to be presented, on Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. through next weekend, is ''Midsummer in the Key of Dreams,'' featuring a hip-hop score, musicians and break dancers ages 12 to 20. Suggested donation $5. Information: (718) 398-0546.
Theater

KINGS COUNTY SHAKESPEARE COMPANY'S FESTIVAL, through Sept. 3 at Founders Hall Theater of St. Francis College, 182 Remsen Street, Brooklyn Heights, will present Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' (tonight at 8) and Richard Brinsley Sheridan's comedy of manners ''The Rivals'' (tomorrow and Sunday at 8) in repertory. For children the highlight will be the preliminary performance at 7:15, ''Shakespeare's Clowns and Villains and Willie's Willful Women,'' featuring comic scenes from the plays, performed by the KCSC Young Company. Also to be presented, on Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. through next weekend, is ''Midsummer in the Key of Dreams,'' featuring a hip-hop score, musicians and break dancers ages 12 to 20. Suggested donation $5. Information: (718) 398-0546.

''ROMEO AND JULIET,'' a 90-minute production featuring masks, music and pageantry by the Lite Theater Company staged amid the open-air classical architecture of steps and columns at the Tennis House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. (Enter the park at Ninth Street and Prospect Park Drive and cross the West Drive.) Audience members may bring blankets or folding chairs. For all ages. Tomorrow at 4 p.m. and Sunday at 7 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 414-7773.

''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' the L. Frank Baum story, featuring a country-and-western score, Sunday at 1:30 and 3:30 p.m. Puppetworks at the Children's Aid Society, Greenwich Village Center Theater, 219 Sullivan Street, between Third and Bleecker Streets. For ages 3 and up. Admission: $8; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718) 965-3391.

''SAIGON WATER PUPPET THEATER,'' the art of Vietnamese water puppetry developed more than 1,000 years ago. Ornately detailed puppets wielded by 15 puppeteers wading waist-deep in a 7,500-gallon pool will enact folk stories set in fishing and farming villages tonight at 7 and tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m. at the World Financial Center Plaza in Battery Park City. Admission is free. Information: (212) 528-2733.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''BEADS, BODY AND SOUL: ART AND LIGHT IN THE YORUBA UNIVERSE,'' an exhibition presented jointly by the Studio Museum in Harlem (through Sept. 17), and the Museum for African Art (through Aug. 27), explores 1,000 years of beaded arts in Yoruba culture. The Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, will give youngsters a chance to make beaded jewelry and watch an artist at work tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, , will present a portraiture workshop tomorrow at 1 p.m. Youngsters should bring a photograph and will paint a self-portrait. Limited to 30 children 5 and older. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly. Call to reserve space for all activities. Information: (212) 966-1313, extension 125.

''BUGS ARE BEAUTIFUL,'' tomorrow and Sunday at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, featuring bug-related programs. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 p.m., a Paper Puppet Presentation of ''Classic Bug Books'' by Eric Carle, in which youngsters will help tell stories about hungry caterpillars and busy spiders with the help of hand puppets. Tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 4 p.m., youngsters will use plaster and spoons to mold and decorate a batch of beetles to take home. Cost is $4 for materials, plus museum admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. Children can also check out the ''Bugs and Other Insects'' exhibition, where they can crawl through an ant hill and watch butterflies hatch. Summer hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (718) 273-2060.

COWBOYS OF COLOR PONY EXPRESS RODEO, will feature a rodeo demonstration, an Indian powwow, trick roping, barrel races, steer wrestling and pony rides, through Sunday. The rodeo is on the Crotona Park North Ball Fields, the Bronx, today at 1 p.m., tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m. and Sunday at 5 p.m., rain or shine. Admission: $8. The rodeo is being held in conjunction with the G.H.I. Bronx Tennis Classic in Crotona Park, which will feature free group tennis lessons daily for adults and children, with USA Tennis pros from the New York Junior Tennis League teaching the basics. Professional singles and doubles matches will also be played on the courts, with free admission. Information: (718) 786-7110, extension 46.

''FISH JUBILEE.'' Activities will focus on the marine life in the Hudson River. There will be big-city fishing, with rod, reel and bait provided free, and workshops on the river's ecosystem in which microscopes will offer a closer look. Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. through August. Piers 25, at North Moore Street, and 40, at Houston Street. Free. Information: (212) 533-7275.

''PASSING ON THE TRADITION 2000,'' with workshops in dance, drumming, steelpan, art and design, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. through Aug. 29 at Medgar Evers College, 1150 Carroll Street, between Rogers and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn. Information: (718) 951-3645. Free.

''SKETCHING TO SEE,'' a sketching workshop focusing on the natural wonders of Central Park, tomorrow from 10:30 a.m. to noon at the Henry Luce Observatory at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street. For ages 10 and older. Free, but registration required. (212) 772-0210.

''STORY CORNER: TRANSFORMATION TALES,'' about animals and native peoples of the Northwest Coast, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the first-floor Hall of the Americas, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''WELCOME TO THE WORLD OF DANCE,'' a performance for children tomorrow at 3 p.m. by Daniel Gwirtzman and his modern dance company in which grown-ups not only go barefoot and wear funny clothes but also run, twirl and leap with abandon. The troupe explains what contemporary choreography is all about, then takes the lesson further by inviting the audience members to join in. Flea Theater, 41 White Street, Lower Manhattan. Tickets: $15. Reservations advised. Information: (212) 226-2407.

''THE WIZARD OF OZ.'' The 1939 classic is to be presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center as part of the Judy Garland film series on Sunday, Aug. 26 and 27 at 11 a.m. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center. Tickets: $3. Information: (212) 875-5601.
Exhibitions

''INVESTIGATING WHERE WE LIVE,'' a summer program offered by the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, exhibits the projects of 20 students ages 12 to 16 from Hamilton Heights and from Long Island City, Queens. The students focus on the architecture, history and urban design of their neighborhoods through photography and journal writing. The results of their work will be on display through Sept. 9. Hours: daily, except Thursdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''LIVING ON THE EDGE,'' an interactive exhibition about the coastal environment, through Aug. 26 at the Queens Library Gallery inside the Queens Borough Public Library's Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica. Visitors can activate a 10-foot-long wave tank, design a coastal landscape by computer, alter water currents with their hands and test their survival skills as a lobster, flounder or plankton. Hours: Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Free. Information: (718) 990-8665.
Zoos
''SNAILS, SNAILS AND RATTLESNAKES'

TAILS.'' These creepy-crawly creatures, some of the least-loved animals, will get a personality makeover to make them more popular tomorrow from 10:30 a.m. to noon (ages 5 to 7) and 2 to 3:30 p.m. (ages 8 to 10) at the Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Fee: $8; $6 for members. Preregistration required. Information: (718) 442-3174 or (718) 442-3101.
